content:
docs#Matrix.stdBasisMatrix i j r (the matrix with a single entry r at i j) has a slightly strange name, especially in that the word Matrix is repeated. I think this suffix is trying to avoid a name clash with docs#Matrix.stdBasis, but this is also a strange name since most other types do not use std to distinguish the "standard" basis, eg docs#Pi.basisFun.

We also have docs#LieAlgebra.SpecialLinear.Eb, which should probably be renamed to match.

Some suggested alternatives:

  • Matrix.E (as suggested by @Johan Commelin in a DM), where the E stands for "elementary". While this breaks the naming convention, it matches docs#Polynomial.X and docs#Polynomial.C
  • Matrix.single, to match docs#Pi.single, docs#Finsupp.single, docs#AddMonoidAlgebra.single, etc

/poll What should this operation be called:

  • Matrix.stdBasisMatrix (status quo)
  • Matrix.single
  • Matrix.E
(if you add an option, please post an explanation of the etymology as a message below)
It's shorter than the status quo, so I think length-wise that's ok; but as I understand it the word means the wrong thing
I would also note that, as another point against stdBasisMatrix: it isn't a basis at all when the matrix is infinite in size. (--> it applies and is meaningful in cases where stdBasis isn't defined.)
I've just noticed that wikipedia calls this construction a "single-entry matrix", so maybe the naming is pretty clear-cut here
Oh you're right about "elementary", I forgot they were defined with 1's on the diagonal
The poll looks fairly one-sided, so I've created #24622
Eric Wieser has marked this topic as resolved.
